comment: I took him for my Physics 1 lab and he's a great instructor. His grading can sometimes be a little wonky, I forgot to do one part (only 4 problems out of the 20 for one section) and got everything right except for those 4 and got a fifty out of one-hundred for that lab so make sure you turn in your lab's 100% complete but besides that, he's great
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Graded by few things--Tough grader

comment: There is always 3 blocks of homework with around 15 questions each for every test covering the subjects on the test. Avoid missing classes because he does not usually go back. Breakout sessions are really good for homework questions you did not get or to clarify other matters.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Clear grading criteria--Lecture heavy

comment: I took Dr. Thackston for both lecture & lab. While the subject is hard, he thoroughly explains each type of problem you may encounter. The formula sheets for the tests are very generous, and the grading system is permissive (you can fail a few assignments and still avg. a 100%). H/W is Web Assign. I look forward to Physics 2 with him next semester!

Took him for Physics I Lecture and Lab over the summer. Does a good job at explaining the material and going over examples. Homework was heavy but not that bad. Test are difficult but the lowest gets replaced with the final which in my opinion was easier than the exams. Would take him again for Physics II if hes available.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Lots of homework--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: Straight forward and easy to understand. Open to dialogue and Answers all questions in class. (He's American, which is a bonus). TOUGH material, and LOTS of web assign hw which is graded for accuracy, not completion (this brought my grade down). FAST grader and provides solutions for all test/quizes next day. Quizes are online. He's a chatty Kathy.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Skip class? You won't pass.--Clear grading criteria

comment: I had him years ago for both PHYS 2211 and 2212 (B and A, respectively.) He's not easy, but definitely knowledgeable. Tough, but I felt like I understood Physics well after taking him.

Thackston is a great guy who knows his stuff. He's super nice but do not let that fool you. His class is super hard. Tests are 9 questions and he tells you to review past hw assignments and noncredit problems to study which totals to about 120 questions for each test. Try to avoid him if you can. Your gpa will thank you.

The first couple of labs were the hardest, but I think it has to do with getting use to the lingo in the lab book. Dr. Thackston knows his stuff and will help you get through a part of the lab if you get stuck. Get to class on time, because if you catch the lecture it helps the lab go more smoothly.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Skip class? You won't pass.--Graded by few things

comment: Thackston breathes physics. One of the most organized courses I have taken. Gives a good bit of homework but it's not bad and it helps a lot. Grading is very generous and you can make over 100 on tests. Gives detailed formula sheets. You can do bad on a couple quizzes yet still make a 100 quiz grade. Fair warning: by no means is this an easy course

Lot of web assign homework. I also did noncredit web assign because they were often used in tests. During lectures, he sometimes skips steps or doesn't fully explain which makes things harder to understand. I studied so much for this class. Took AP Physics in high school, and I'd say he makes it harder to understand than it should be.
rating_tags: LOTS OF HOMEWORK--Clear grading criteria--TEST HEAVY

comment: Avoid this professor at all cost!

I think the subject (Physics 2) is just plain hard but he made it as easy to digest as possible. He gives good examples and physical representations and background info for the material. You get more formula sheet for tests than other professors give, which is a life saver.

He is a boring old guy, BUT a great physics professor. If you can just sit and pay attention, you will do just fine in his course. That is granted you show up to class and do homework on webassign. It's really not a hard class. He allows you to use a formula sheet/ cheat sheet and attendance isn't required. You can get an A if you just try.
rating_tags: LOTS OF HOMEWORK--Clear grading criteria--TEST HEAVY

comment: Tough guy. He means well, but it was the hardest thing ive ever done. He gets going on problems and doesn't stop. If you want him to work an example he usually just explains it to you instead. The breakouts are sometimes helpful. The final was easier but still difficult. He says he doesn't curve the final grade, but he made a C a 65. Lab was easy.
rating_tags: Tough Grader--Skip class? You won't pass.--Tests are tough

comment: He's just so smart I think it's hard for him to explain things in terms other people can understand. It's just plainly a really hard class. You can do all the homework and review notes, and still only pull off a C on his tests. He is loud enough and writes clearly on the whiteboard. He likes to derive the formulas you'll use.

If your major requires the skills and knowledge of knowing basic physics this is the professor to take. He implants the knowledge through his lecture and makes you work very hard for the tests. Even though I received a grade of C I would take him again. I gained far more from this class than other students who received an A, with another professor.

Not a bad prof. I failed physics 1 once, am taking him my second time and it's a vast improvement. The subject is difficult, but he tries his best to explain it with real world examples and such. Easy to understand (speaking+writing). A lot of homework, but thats for the best. He also provides formula sheets for tests, which are useful for homework
Overall he really understands and knows how to teach physics. The class is just very dry and boring. I took it over the summer and got a B. Getting an A definitely is hard but doable.

I don't know why he gets such a bad rap. You have to work for it, yes, but if you do and understand all of the homework (not just webassign, there are other nongraded homework), you can definitely make a A. Tests actually have more points than necessary, so you can miss some but still make a 100. He has a lot of office hours and is very friendly.
I had him for PHYS 2111L and PHYS 2212L. He is a really good lab professor. Just be consistent with your sig figs and graphs, and you will done fine.

Mr. Thackston is a decent professor. He is definately the best professor out there but, if you want to learn physics take him. The class material might seem confusing at times but he explains throughly. Gives extra credit too.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Clear grading criteria--EXTRA CREDIT

comment: Great professor for lab, follow the guidelines in the lab manual to the letter and make sure you pay attention to your units & sig figs. Do this & youll be good. I wouldn't recommend him for 2211 Lecture though.
rating_tags: Tough Grader--Skip class? You won't pass.--ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS

comment: The tests he gives are nothing like the homework that you do. His tests are very difficult and he likes to derive formulas in class. When it comes to the final, he tests you over material that he did not put on his previous tests. Take another professor if you have the chance.

Be prepared to study nonstop on your own. Dr. Thackston is a brilliant human calculator but can often assume you know the formulas and his algebra just as good as he does. Web assign problems can be hard. Rely on knowing how to manipulate the formulas on his provided formula sheets. A portion of the final can replace a bad test so ride it out

Dr. Thackston is an awesome person, very kind, and he wants to see his students succeed, but if you do not study you will not pass his class. There are a lot of difficult homework problems assigned in webassign. There are 5 exams, 7 quizzes, and a final. Start strong ,do not get behind, and expect to spend a lot of time studying. Very tough class!!

Dr. Thackston was a pretty tough professor. Being in class is not mandatory but its necessary if you wanna pass. Do ALL of the webassign homework and show up to recitation for quizzes to balance out how bad you will do on tests. Doing webassign also wont be enough, he takes a lot of problems from the suggested book problems he gives you so do those

Nice guy but all he does in class is examples on the board, he assumes you already know the concepts and does nothing with them even though they are on every test. Not very helpful during office hours either, ask him a physics question and he will end up off on a random tangent that has nothing to do with physics.

Physics 1 calc based. I was told he was one of the hardest teachers. Lectures are not clear all the time, and his test are VERY difficult. He definitely knows everything about physics and likes to teach, but if you dont do the homework and webassign, youll most likely get lost or very upset when you see your test. If you take him, do the homework.

Dr. Thackston is a Physics wiz. He really cares about his students and will not let them be spoon fed a grade. Do all the homework and know the formula sheet and then some before you go into the exams. Lowest test grade can be replaced with a section from the final exam. Be prepared to work hard, Physics 2 is not an easy class.

Thackston is a very smart man.  He is always willing to help and explain things. Go to his office whenever have questions. The tests are hard. DO ALL THE ASSIGNED BOOK PROBLEMS, these are on the tests give or take. An A is achievable if you start strong, take notes, do all homework assigned (incl webassign) and ask for help. Fantastic Professor!

My impression of this class: do the webassign, I got this. First test, WTF is this. Get the test back. Ohhhh, that is how you do it. It continues like this for the rest of the semester. Tests are very difficult. Doing well on webassign is must to offset poor test grades. Do all the extra problems not on webassign. Really understand these.

A very tough course.Do the homework on webassign and understand it inside and out, half of his test questions are based off of the homework formatted in a different way.There are two or three concept questions per test. He picks some of his concept questions from the book, so do those "quick quizzes" that is in the textbook

While physics is not by any means an easy class, Dr. Thackston manages to make it possible to get a good grade. His tests are difficult, but you can offset a lackluster test grade or two with good grades on quizzes and homework. He is also very helpful if you have trouble on homework. I would definitely take him again.

Dr. Thackson is a great professor.  However, as with any Physics class, do not expect that going to class alone is going to be enough to earn you an A. DO the homework. Dr. Thackston is more than willing to help if you come to his office with questions. Also a great lecturer overall.

I'm taking Logic, Circuits II and Statistics with this course. I have an A in the mentioned above, and a C in this course so far. -_- The Tests are... fair, just do your homework. You really need to understand the concepts as well as the equations if you want to do well. Thackston is very helpful during office hours, take advantage.

One of the smartest men you will ever meet when it comes to physics.  Too smart.. Gives basics in class and on test expects you to be able to solve stuff you've never seen before.  Highest grade on the first test was 78.  Average was 44. Stay away unless you know physics in and out.
I don't understand why there are so many complaints about him. I thought he was good. The only reason I got a B is because I was a slacker, especially when it came to WebAssign

One of the nicest guys I've ever met & a great conversationalist-But, he's taught phys at SPSU since ~'83 so he knows the material too well-He skips concepts & learning devices that we as novices need to know b/c it doesn't occur to him that they're not obvious-If you have a phys foundation, take him-If you need more coaching-take someone else.
Tests do not reflect lecture. Very unclear and not helpful at all.he is very hard.

WOW!!! he is SO hard it is crazy. Not one person understands him. He doesnt know how to teach. All he does is work out problems and never explains them. Also, his test are crazy. Don't take him if you need physics.

very difficult. he derives every formula which seemed like a waste of time. he's a really nice guy who knows his physics but it's so easy to him he doesn't see how it could NOT be easy. struggled to get by. lecture didn't really help with the homework. helps you 1-1 if you see him but otherwise you'll be teaching yourself through this class.
He does a very good job at teaching what is normally considered an "insanely hard" subject. I didn't find it too difficult myself, though. Very good 'A' if you earn it.

Dr. Thackston's knowledge of physics is phenomenal! He's very helpful and friendly. There is no doubt that the subject matter is VERY difficult, but he takes the time to explain it in detail, until it is understood. I would definitely recommend doing the homework, and studying for the exams...especially exam #1. EXCELLENT teacher!!

Excellent instructor who really knows physics. PHYS 2212 is a hard subject and the first test is the hardest test. His grading system give you every opportunity to do well. I missed an A by two points and that is with making a 50% on the first test! I would definitely take him for additional classes and I recommend everyone take him if you can.

Best grading system I've experienced. Very fair but no "give me" on grading. You have to work for your grade but making an A is possible. You must turn in homework and take the quizzes to have a chance of making an A.

I loved physics 1 and had an A+ in it but I now never want anything to do with physics again in my life. His teaching method of drawing a picture then deriving a formula while explaining nothing at all is completely useless to me, I feel like the only thing I am learning is from reading the book.
Excellent physicist and professor. Thorough and will answer questions in a friendly manner. Knows his physics and has a fair grading policy. Got an "A" but had to study hard to get it.

Took 2111 with him and came back for 2112. Dr. Thackston is truly a genious and an inspiration. The subject matter is not easy and he does not "dumb it down" either, rather he reinforces it with his own knowledge. Dr. Thackston is a caring and learned teacher who wants the best for his students. Extremely helpful and nice, thank you Dr. Thackston!!

AVOID TAKING HIM!  The tests are ridiculously long!  I studied the lectures from MIT, the book MIT uses, Thackston's lecture notes, and the book for this course.  Yet I still was not able to complete the test within the time period given.  Even MIT (ranked #1 in physics) does not give tests as long as Thackston's.  Take Whitenton instead.

Dr. Thackston is the nicest professor I have delt with, always very helpful and respectful of students. Recitations may have 2-question long pop quizzes but they are open book. Tests are tricky but approachable. Do yor homework for extra points. The final was extremely fair! Good A if you work for the class. Dr. Thackst rules, period.

I only had Thackston for lab. He is a good lab instructor, very helpful with any questions. His grading is strict but as long as you follow the procedure in the manual, especially with the graphs, you should be fine.
He's tough, but very fair. He gave me points back on a Multiple choice problem I messed up on, because I showed the work and how my calculator messed up.
He was a great teacher, and his grading policy was pretty fair.  But if you don't do the homework, you're in big trouble!  If you don't stay on top of this class, it can be very difficult.

I got an A in the class by doing the homework. Most of it wasn't too hard. If I couldn't work it out myself I just copied it from the solutions manual. To study for the tests I worked through the homework again. The questions were close to the homework. He also took up random homework problems that made up 10% of the final grade. Do the homework!!!
Hard. He knew exactly what he was talking about but the problem was I never knew what he was talking about.
No Comments
Rigerous in the classroom, but a nice guy if you ask for 1 on 1 help.  Don't be intimidated to ask for help.  Tough subject matter, but he grades very fairly.
Tests do not reflect lecture. Very unclear and not helpful at all.

I hardly had to refer to the text, the examples from lecture were sufficient He gives many chances for extra credit.keep up with homework and turn it in for credit, every test has extra credit. alot of students do badly in his class, but I got an A, and I fell behind alot (didn't turn in homeworks)
No Comments
the guy that left the rating before nows what hes talking about, dont take him if you have a choice

WOW!!! he is SO hard it is crazy.  Not one person understands him.  He doesnt know how to teach.  All he does is work out problems and never explains them.  Also, his test are crazy. Don't take him if you need physics
